channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trade Fueled Inequality. Can Trump’s Tariffs Reduce It?
item.description: The president has pitched his trade policies at workers who feel left behind by globalization. But that doesn’t mean trade barriers will revive factories and close income gaps.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Fires BLS Commissioner, Claiming Weak Jobs Numbers Were ‘Rigged’
item.description: Economists said ousting the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics could undermine confidence in government economic data.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Tony Romm

item.title: Harm or Help? Why Companies Are Battling Tariffs Meant to Benefit Them.
item.description: Economists say the way the Trump administration is imposing tariffs is backfiring for some of the businesses they are meant to help.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Stocks Drop as Trump’s New Tariffs Weigh on Markets
item.description: Data showing cracks in the U.S. labor market and President Trump’s newest barrage of tariffs shook investors around the world, weighing on stocks, the dollar and more.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye

item.title: Fed Governor Resigns, Giving Trump Opportunity to Shape Central Bank
item.description: The resignation comes as President Trump has openly pressured the central bank to lower interest rates and called for Jerome H. Powell, the chair, to step down.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith

item.title: Here is the latest.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm, Ben Casselman, Sydney Ember, River Akira Davis and Lydia DePillis

item.title: Stock Market Posts Worst Week in Months on Renewed Economic Fears
item.description: Data showing cracks in the U.S. labor market and President Trump’s newest barrage of tariffs shook investors around the world, weighing on stocks, the dollar and more.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye

item.title: Trump Turns to Untested Tariffs to Reorder Global Trade
item.description: President Trump has long wanted to rework world trade. The tariffs set to go into effect next week will carry out that plan.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Switzerland Is Stunned by 39% U.S. Tariff, Among the Highest in the World
item.description: Swiss officials plan to negotiate urgently for a lower rate, before the punishing levy takes effect next week.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman

item.title: Cambodia Agrees to a Reduced Tariff and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
item.description: Initially 49%, it was lowered to 19%, easing worries of a damaging hit to the country’s garment and footwear production industries.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

item.title: India Reels From the Shock of Trump’s Onslaught
item.description: Russian oil poses just one problem. Business groups are flummoxed by the variety and vagueness of the American president’s complaints.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli

item.title: Recent global trade deals with the U.S. were secured with murky investments.
item.description: were secured with huge, often vaguely defined investment pledges from partners like Japan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: How Tariffs Raise Costs for Farmers, Making Food More Expensive
item.description: The latest round of tariffs is likely to make agricultural production even more expensive and, potentially, limit access to goods not produced in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper

item.title: Federal Government Shed 12,000 Jobs in July
item.description: The U.S. government has lost 84,000 jobs since January as the Trump administration aggressively reduces the work force.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Eileen Sullivan

item.title: Who Pays for U.S. Tariffs, and Where Does the Money Go?
item.description: President Trump is seeking to raise federal revenue by imposing levies on goods from foreign nations. Here’s how the process works.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Big Downward Jobs Revisions Could Be a Warning Sign for the Economy
item.description: Employers added far fewer jobs in May and June than previously reported. Such downgrades have historically meant trouble for the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Weak Jobs Report Raises Chances of a September Interest Rate Cut
item.description: The Federal Reserve held rates steady in July but two governors dissented, saying they had concerns about labor market fragility.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Colby Smith

item.title: South Korea Reaches Trade Deal With Trump
item.description: The agreement comes after other American allies, like Japan, clinched their own deals, partly to moderate President Trump’s tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Countries Promise Trump to Buy U.S. Gas, and Leave the Details for Later
item.description: U.S. trading partners are committing to buy more gas than they need or than the U.S. can produce, at least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Rebecca F. Elliott

item.title: Trump Targets Copper With Tariffs, Though Not as Aggressively as Expected
item.description: The president stopped short of putting a 50 percent tariff on refined copper, as he had threatened earlier this year. The market reaction was swift anyway and prices tumbled.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: See How Often Two Fed Governors Have Dissented on a Rate Change Vote
item.description: Two top Fed officials voted against the central bank’s decision to leave rates unchanged, the first dual dissent in more than 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Christine Zhang

item.title: I.M.F. Raises Global Growth Outlook as U.S. Eases Some Tariffs
item.description: The International Monetary Fund warned that trade tension continued to be a risk for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Trump Is Winning His Trade War. What Will That Mean for the Economy?
item.description: The president’s vision for reshaping global trade is falling into place, but he is embarking on an experiment that economists say could still produce damaging results.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
